case_vignette: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of fever, malaise, and severe right knee joint pain and swelling for 3 days. He had also had episodes of abdominal pain and epistaxis during this period. Five days ago, he had swelling and pain in his left ankle joint which has since resolved. He reports having a sore throat 3 weeks ago while he was camping in the woods, for which he received symptomatic treatment. His immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 38.7°C (101.6°F), pulse is 119/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Examination shows a swollen, tender right knee; range of motion is limited. There are painless 3- to 4-mm nodules over the elbow. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. His hemoglobin concentration is 12.3 g/dL, leukocyte count is 11,800/mm3, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 58 mm/h. Arthrocentesis of the right knee joint yields clear, straw-colored fluid; no organisms are identified on Gram stain. Analysis of the synovial fluid shows a leukocyte count of 1,350/mm3 with 17% neutrophils.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Rheumatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having a fever, feeling generally unwell, and I'm experiencing severe pain and swelling in my right knee that's been going on for 3 days now.
How old are you and what is your sex?
I am a 14-year-old boy.
Have you had any injury or trauma to your knee recently?
No, I haven't had any injury or trauma to my knee recently.
Do you have a history of similar joint problems or any other chronic illnesses?
My left ankle was swollen and painful about 5 days ago, but it has since gotten better; other than that, I don't have a history of joint problems or chronic illnesses.
Have you noticed any skin rashes, eye redness, or infections recently?
No, I haven't noticed any skin rashes, eye redness, or infections recently.
Has anyone in your family been diagnosed with arthritis or any other autoimmune diseases?
I can't give you information about my family's medical history; I can only describe my symptoms.
Understood. Have you started any new medications or have you been sick recently?
I had a sore throat 3 weeks ago while I was camping in the woods and received treatment for the symptoms.
Do you recall if you had tick bites or were exposed to insects during your camping trip?
I can't specify any insect or tick bites, I'm just able to describe the sore throat I had during the camping trip.
Has the swelling in your knee limited your ability to walk or bear weight on that leg?
Yes, the swelling in my knee has limited my ability to move it and I'm having trouble using that leg.
Have you experienced a fever that fluctuates during the day, particularly with higher temperatures in the evenings?
My fever has been ongoing, but I haven't mentioned anything about fluctuations throughout the day.
Has the pain in your knee responded to any over-the-counter medications or home treatments?
I haven't mentioned trying any over-the-counter medications or home treatments for my knee pain.
Are there any other symptoms such as shortness of breath, chest pain, or palpitations that you have noticed?
My breathing and chest seem normal; I haven't experienced any shortness of breath, chest pain, or palpitations.

Final Diagnosis: Given the age, the migratory joint swelling and pain without injury or chronic disease history, and a sore throat a few weeks prior, the most likely diagnosis is acute rheumatic fever.
